channel.title: Cable modem
channel.description:
Okay so...long story short...
I bought the ac router from best buy and it came. APPARENTLY my cable modem does not do n/ac...
I am interested in buying a cable modem that does do both n/ac both but I have been unable thus far to find one little help please?
Here is the ac/n topic from before:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,638167.0.html

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:15, topic:519933”]That makes no sense, all routers/modems must follow the 7 layer OSI model, these are a set of protocols which define networking, it’s obviously a problem with drivers/your adapter which causes them to not be compatible…[/quote]I know it sounds crazy cause I thought the exact thing lol:o

for some very odd reason I could connect up my original cable modem/old cisco router and get wifi/use wired connections at the 25mbps like I used to with absolutely no issue but when I go to swap to the new router/wired connection it says it’s connected under network connections but I go to a webpage and it tries to give me the bologna that the site cannot be displayed cause of connection issues or whatever.

Weird I know…I tested this theory with four different computers ( 2 desktops, 2 laptops…)

the older laptop I originally used to set up my OLD router didn’t work with N/AC…
the newer laptop worked perfectly
the older desktop didn’t work with N/AC(It had like Windows ME on it…)
the semi newer/but still somewhat crappy desktop worked on the 2.4ghz but not the AC for some odd reason (it has vista)

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

That makes no sense, all routers/modems must follow the 7 layer OSI model, these are a set of protocols which define networking, it’s obviously a problem with drivers/your adapter which causes them to not be compatible…

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Rash, post:12, topic:519933”]are you marvin or majorie[/quote]lol marvin is my dad I was just using his account

[hr]

[quote=“jme, post:13, topic:519933”]So maybe you aren’t setting it up properly? do you have the correct ppoe credentials?(they are case sensitive also)

You have tried a wired connection from modem to pc. How about a wired connection from your router to pc? If that doesn’t work it must be wrong pppoe password or something.[/quote]resolved it just a few minutes ago. Apparently for some god forsaken reason they have made it so the newer cable modems/routers are NOT compatible with Windows XP… freaking conspiracies to force you to buy newer products…

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

So maybe you aren’t setting it up properly? do you have the correct ppoe credentials?(they are case sensitive also)

You have tried a wired connection from modem to pc. How about a wired connection from your router to pc? If that doesn’t work it must be wrong pppoe password or something.

Read full topic

item.description:
@rash wrote:

are you marvin or majorie

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:10, topic:519933”]I think you are wrong. The cable modem has nothing to do with what bands the router is using. It isn’t the one “reading” the bands, that’s all done by the router.

Does the 6121 motorola surfboard 3.0 have a built in wireless router? If so, that’s what the b/g limitation is on. Doesn’t prevent you from using a different router.[/quote]the 6121 model which I have is only a cable modem. WHen I go to the netgear gateway 192.168.1.1. in chrome/whatever it opens the router firewall etc up. I go to do initial setup and all and it says it’s trying to find any compatible detections… but then it gives an error trying to say it can’t find any. I can’t even test the speed if I can’t get past the initial setup…as far as I know Comcast uses pppoe or something like that and it has to be dynamic(unless you buy a business static ip…)

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

I think you are wrong. The cable modem has nothing to do with what bands the router is using. It isn’t the one “reading” the bands, that’s all done by the router.

Does the 6121 motorola surfboard 3.0 have a built in wireless router? If so, that’s what the b/g limitation is on. Doesn’t prevent you from using a different router.

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:8, topic:519933”]Just answer me this…

You purchased an 802.11ac router, along with the adapter. You also own a cable modem obviously.

Does your cable modem plug into the router with a rj45 cable? If so, you do not need a new modem. The problem is with your router, configuration, or interference.[/quote]the router and the cable modem is connected via a cat6 cable. The cable modem is a 6121 motorola surfboard 3.0 which only supports B/G band.

[quote=“jme, post:7, topic:519933”]Ok I probably don’t know what I am talking about,

To me it doesn’t make sense that your modem wouldn’t be compatible. Are you sure about this? It leaves the modem on ethernet(?) which plugs into router, which will broadcast 802.11ac. I don’t understand how 802.11ac router can’t be compatible with any modem since they have nothing to do with each other? It wouldn’t hurt calling netgear. See what they have to say. (note my experience with them is that they blame pc issues and want money to fix those pc issues)

Or maybe I have a serious misunderstanding of all this… I was a dsl technician and never a cable customer.[/quote]cable modems have band limitations. They can only read specific bands such as b/g/n/ac

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Just answer me this…

You purchased an 802.11ac router, along with the adapter. You also own a cable modem obviously.

Does your cable modem plug into the router with a rj45 cable? If so, you do not need a new modem. The problem is with your router, configuration, or interference.

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Ok I probably don’t know what I am talking about,

To me it doesn’t make sense that your modem wouldn’t be compatible. Are you sure about this? It leaves the modem on ethernet(?) which plugs into router, which will broadcast 802.11ac. I don’t understand how 802.11ac router can’t be compatible with any modem since they have nothing to do with each other? It wouldn’t hurt calling netgear. See what they have to say. (note my experience with them is that they blame pc issues and want money to fix those pc issues)

Or maybe I have a serious misunderstanding of all this… I was a dsl technician and never a cable customer.

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:5, topic:519933”]Just curious, what kind of results do you get on speedtest.net?

In my experience, it doesn’t matter what kind of router/modem setup you have, I will always get the same speeds (around 5mbps).[/quote]On a wired connection I max at about 63-65mbps with about 10 mbps upload

On a wireless connection atm using my old cisco small business router I am maxing at about 22-25mbps.

I am paying for 50mbps so on Comcast side they are supplying the proper speed at the moment. In the future though if I ever wanted to get a 500mbps connection or something ( don’t even ask why this is just hypothetical…) I want to make sure I have the BEST equipment possible to use the full force of that speed.

I find it strange that BestBuy/other resellers are selling AC band type routers/adapters however there are no cable modems to go alone with this.

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Just curious, what kind of results do you get on speedtest.net?

In my experience, it doesn’t matter what kind of router/modem setup you have, I will always get the same speeds (around 5mbps).

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Aah Comcast, had them when I lived in Michigan. Great speeds with very poor customer service. I wish I had anything else to say.

Read full topic

item.title: Cable modem
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:2, topic:519933”]Prolly call your ISP and see if there is a modem they can sell you that will work.[/quote]You have never used comcast have you? xD… here is a short view of my chat thus far

Marvin: My Issue: I recently purchased an 802.11ac wireless dual band router which picks up 2.4ghz and 5ghz frequencies. ( so it does broadcast for wireless n and ac) plus a corresponding wireless adapter for ac/n. I need answers to a few questions

analyst Marjorie has entered room

Marjorie: Hello Marvin, Thank you for contacting Comcast Live Chat Support. My name is Marjorie. Please give me one moment to review your information.

Marjorie: My pleasure to have you on this chat! I always remain committed and focused to provide you quality customer service at my fullest effort. Before anything else, I honestly hope you are doing well. Please give me a minute to check the information you provided before the chat started.

Marvin: 1) Does Comcast know of any 802.11ac cable modems that can be used for such a router?

Marjorie: Hi, Marvin. I understand that you have questions about your new Gateway device. Rest assured that I will do my best to answer all your concerns today about the device.

Marjorie: Please verify the make and model of your new modem so that I can check?

Marjorie: If your it’s wireless capable?

Marvin: er one second let me get the model and I will also link to best buy site where it was bought

Marvin: this is the router I purchased

Marvin: http://netgear.com/home/products/wirelessrouters/ultimate-performance/R6300.aspx

Marvin: and yes it is a wireless router

Marvin: this is the box you would connect to the modem to create a wireless signal

Marjorie: THank you for this information.

Marvin: i currently have an older cisco i am using but I recently upgraded to a 50mbps and my current router maxes at 25mbps so I am trying to do some upgrading for the future if that makes sense

Marvin: I can easily get a cable modem that supplies a wireless n connection but I am hoping to find one that supplies for a wireless ac

Marvin: Bestbuy referred me to my isp ( you guys ) so here I am

Marjorie: I can see in here that you’re already using the Doc3.0 modem which is the updated one. Any routers are compatible with your device, given that it’s properly configured so that the speed that your modem will provide will sync with your router.

Marvin: the doc 3.0 according to the back of the box only runs up to a wireless g

Marvin: hence the max of 25mbps

Marjorie: What’s matter most is that there will be no signal strength disruption from your router. When the signal is weak, the connection becomes slow to a certain point and will drop at random times.

Marvin: its the particular model that is

Marvin: i have a 6120 or something like that the 3.0 that offers the wireless N is 6180 but like I said I’d rather get a modem that supplies ac

Marjorie: Have you tried connecting your computer directly to the modem and test if you can get a 50MB speed?

Marvin: yes wire wise I can get it, I am trying to get wireless setup ( I know how to do it so I don’t need a house call or anything )

Marvin: I just need isp advice on where to get a modem

Marjorie: Thank you for this information. So this means that your router settings needs to be configured in order to be sync with your modem data. You’ll need to contact netgear support @ 1-888-638-4327 or use this link: http://www.netgear.com/About/ContactUs.aspx . You’ll just need to contact them and inform them that the speed results using direct and wireless connection have high difference.

Marjorie: THey will be changing some settings in your router so that you will get the actual speed your modem is giving you.

Marvin: I don’t think you quite understand the current doc 3.0 model of a router I have is not compatible

Marvin: the 6120 only goes up to 802.11g connection ( 25mb and less )

Marvin: As I stated I have purchased a newer router and I am trying to find out if Comcast has a newer cable modem they can suggest

Marjorie: I can see in here that you’re already using SB6121. Right?

Marvin: yes, the 6121 is the one I am referring to that is not compatible

Marjorie: You can use this link: http://mydeviceinfo.comcast.net/ for your modem reference. The recommended device are Doc3.0 with three stars.

Marvin: okay here is the link

Marvin: http://mydeviceinfo.comcast.net/device.php?tier=-1&devid=67&e=0&d2=0&d3=1&s=&so=&sc=800

Marvin: now go to this link

Marvin: under product overview

Marvin: http://moto.arrisi.com/Video-Solutions/US-EN/Solutions/Cable-Operators/Cable-Broadband/Cable-Broadband_US-EN

Marvin: It states that it only goes up to g

Marvin: and by the way I have already confirmed this with motorola

Marjorie: I am now checking the link that you provided.

Marvin: they even told me that this is only a g connection

Marvin: MOTOROLA IS HELPING OPERATORS: Deliver downstream throughput of up to 300 Mbps and upstream throughput of up to 100 Mbps

Marvin: an AC connection which I hope to get sometime would offer speeds up to 1300mbps

Marvin: this is why I am asking if comcast has an ac modem they can suggest…

Marjorie: Marvin, I am not very particular with modem performance,however, the mydevice link are the list of devices that are compatible with Comcast internet service.

Marvin: Marjorie if you cannot assist me can you please esculate my issue to the next technical level so I can speak with another representative please.

They are complete imbeciles…

Read full topic
